job_title: Registered Nurse, Emergency Room in Las Vegas, NV
pros: great team work. lots of staff have been here many years.
cons: difficult patient population. Broken equipment, aging facility

job_title: Critical Care Float RN in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Most people are genuinely nice and helpful. Free coffee for staff in the cafeteria. Teaching hospital environment.
cons: As a critical care float nurse, you will never see the inside of an ICU after your orientation is over. You will always be floated to the emergency room to take care of stepdown and telemetry patients. ICU patients awaiting transfer in the ER are cared for by other ER nurses or staff ICU nurses that are floated to ER. If you value your skills as an ICU nurse, they will not be utilized in this float position at all.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Las Vegas, NV
pros: People are nice and work hard.
cons: Given too much to do as our assignment.

job_title: PSR I in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great benefits for all family members.
cons: Lack of employee training and shortage on staff

review_title: Not as bad as most would think :)
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
Collectively a great group of people to work with (including every department) 
Relatively easy to transfer to a different unit or gain experience in higher levels of care (I.e. med surg nurse to ICU)
Currently union is still in place to check administration when they come up with crazy policies
cons:
Understaffing and floating you off your unit
No raises until agreement between admin and the union 
Typical pizza parties and ice cream to say thank you (can we get a bonus or something we’ll actually use??)

review_title: The staff are the greatest you will work with

job_title: EVS Attendant in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Meeting new people/patients and there’s always something new everyday. If you like a fast paced work environment this is for you.
cons: Management wasn’t there, lack of communication, false security.. they say to be open and tell them what’s bad and whats not but do not take anything into consideration. HR is useless. No union (certain hospitals). They will not work with a schedule if you are trying to do school/work. Will not train you the right way, then hold you accountable for not knowing how to do something.

most shifts are short on many units due to call offs and people quitting. This makes the ratios horrible and the environment very stressful for everyone

job_title: Occupational Therapist in Las Vegas, NV

cons: Difficult demographics are very challenging

job_title: Mental Health Tech in Las Vegas, NV
pros: I love what I do and I do like the company overall. The benefits are pretty good, and one can pick up extra shifts at sister hospitals.
cons: Unorganized, the unit is ran poorly and unprofessionally. Management plays favoritism amongst staff. They will cancel your shift and force you to use PTO when there's staff who's per diem and or has OT for the week. Yes change can be beneficial but they're constantly making changes by word of mouth then turn around and revise or reverse those changes so you dont know if you're coming or going. The communication sucks! They apparently had never heard of memos. They make their own rules, and don't follow hospital policy, and when the do, it's only directed to whomever they're targeting at that moment. The tech supervisor is a big joke whom can't make eye contact, suffers from extreme memory loss and coordination. They micromanage the hell out of techs but let the nurses do what they want, treat the patients like kids, no structure, no consequence and no rehabilitation, just so they can keep coming back.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Friendly coworkers, big hospital, paid training
cons: Management was not professional, did not care about safety of workers

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
Majority of people are pleasant to work with.  
The manager really cares about the staff.
Infectious disease doctor sets standards for nurses.
cons:
Culture of VHS is that when a nurse is pulled from another unit, they get the difficult run of patients with higher acuities.
High turn over rate of staff.
The patient demographic is difficult to educate as they are non-compliant.
One charge nurse, in particular, doesn’t help the staff.  The charge nurse ORDERS  nurses and CNA to do things but does not help.  The charge nurse can be unprofessional, looks down on staff, condesending, and unfriendly.  The charge nurse is the “boss” and is only friendly to upper management and those she get along with AKA those who don’t complain. The charge nurse also comes to work 3 hours before shift unannounced and makes it clear that she is the charge around.  She’s really good at throwing her staff under the bus.  She doesn’t care.

review_title: Good place to start your nursing career. Much help is needed.
job_title: Emergency Department RN in Las Vegas, NV
pros: If looking for a place to start, this is a great place to get experience.  Diverse group of patients, from low income to high income clientele. If you can survive here, you can make it anywhere.
cons: You will either sink or swim. During the "sick" season it will test your ability to keep your composure as well as deliver proper patient care. I would be careful with the assignments. They have a tendency to staff for the numbers and not for the patients.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
RN managers kind, open-door policy
Good compensation
Flexible schedule
Plenty of learning opportunities - teaching hospital
cons:
Frequently understaffed
Regular staff in various stages of burnout
EKG team furloughed during COVID crisis, have not been reinstated. RNs perform most EKGs.

review_title: It was a phlebotomy job, if your experienced look else where

good benefits
